concepts.name: Multi-Scored Sleep Databases
concepts.description: Sleep datasets annotated by multiple experts, capturing inter-rater variability in sleep staging. These databases enable the study of consensus and disagreement among human scorers, providing richer training signals for automated systems.

concepts.name: Soft Consensus Label Smoothing
concepts.description: A novel technique that models expert annotations as a probability distribution rather than a single consensus label. It smooths labels using the empirical distribution of multiple scorers, preserving variability while promoting alignment with group consensus.

concepts.name: Label Smoothing
concepts.description: A regularization technique that prevents overconfidence in model predictions by replacing hard labels with soft distributions. In this work, it is applied to multi-expert annotations to improve generalization and robustness.

concepts.name: Sleep Density Map
concepts.description: A continuous representation of sleep stage distribution over time, generated by models to reflect the temporal dynamics of sleep architecture. It serves as a key output for evaluating model performance against expert consensus.

concepts.name: Expert Consensus
concepts.description: The aggregated judgment of multiple sleep experts, typically used as a gold standard in sleep scoring. In this study, it is treated as a target distribution rather than a discrete label.

concepts.name: Inter-Rater Variability
concepts.description: The degree of disagreement among human sleep scorers when annotating the same polysomnographic data. This variability is modeled as informative signal rather than noise in the proposed method.

concepts.name: Averaged Cosine Similarity
concepts.description: A novel evaluation metric introduced to quantify the similarity between model-generated sleep density maps and expert consensus. It measures angular similarity in high-dimensional space, capturing temporal alignment and pattern fidelity.

concepts.name: Lightweight Deep Learning Models
concepts.description: Efficient neural network architectures designed for low computational cost and fast inference. Used in this study to demonstrate scalability and practical deployment potential of the LSSC method.

concepts.name: Automated Sleep Scoring
concepts.description: The use of machine learning to classify sleep stages from polysomnographic signals. This paper advances the field by incorporating multi-expert variability into the training process.

concepts.name: Probability Distribution Input
concepts.description: A method of representing expert annotations as continuous probability distributions over sleep stages. This allows models to learn from uncertainty and disagreement, improving robustness and interpretability.

concepts.name: Group Consensus Encoding
concepts.description: The ability of a model to learn and represent collective expert judgment from multiple individual annotations. The LSSC method enables this by modeling consensus as a smoothed distribution.

concepts.name: Temporal Pattern Fidelity
concepts.description: The accuracy with which a model reproduces the temporal structure of sleep stages. Evaluated via density maps and cosine similarity, this reflects clinical relevance and physiological plausibility.

concepts.name: Subjective Disagreement Modeling
concepts.description: The intentional incorporation of human scoring inconsistencies as meaningful data rather than noise. This approach enhances model robustness and realism in clinical settings.

concepts.name: Polysomnographic Data
concepts.description: Multimodal physiological recordings (EEG, EOG, EMG) used to assess sleep stages. The primary data source for automated sleep scoring in this study.

concepts.name: Consensus Distribution
concepts.description: The statistical distribution of expert annotations across sleep stages, used as a target for model training. It captures both agreement and disagreement patterns.

concepts.name: Model Generalization
concepts.description: The ability of a trained model to perform well on unseen data. The LSSC method improves generalization by exposing models to diverse expert perspectives during training.

concepts.name: Clinical Applicability
concepts.description: The practical utility of automated sleep scoring systems in real-world medical environments. The study emphasizes improved reliability through better consensus modeling.

concepts.name: Sleep Architecture
concepts.description: The temporal organization of sleep stages across the night, including transitions and durations. Accurate modeling of this structure is critical for clinical diagnosis.

concepts.name: Data Efficiency
concepts.description: The ability to achieve high performance with limited or moderately sized datasets. The lightweight models and LSSC method contribute to this by maximizing information from multi-label data.

concepts.name: Robustness to Annotation Noise
concepts.description: The model’s ability to maintain performance despite inconsistent or noisy expert labels. The LSSC method enhances robustness by treating variability as informative.

concepts.name: Temporal Alignment
concepts.description: The synchronization of model outputs with the true temporal progression of sleep stages. Evaluated via cosine similarity between density maps.

concepts.name: Multi-Label Learning
concepts.description: A machine learning paradigm where each sample is associated with multiple labels. Applied here to sleep scoring with multiple expert annotations per epoch.

concepts.name: Deep Convolutional Networks
concepts.description: Neural network architectures using convolutional layers to extract spatial-temporal features from sleep signals. Used in the study as the underlying model structure.

concepts.name: Probability Calibration
concepts.description: The process of ensuring model output probabilities reflect true confidence. LSSC contributes to better calibration by learning from real expert distributions.

concepts.name: Sleep Stage Classification
concepts.description: The task of assigning each time segment of polysomnography to a sleep stage (e.g., N1, N2, N3, REM). The core objective of automated sleep scoring.

concepts.name: Distributed Expert Judgment
concepts.description: The collective input of multiple sleep experts, treated as a distribution rather than a single value. This forms the basis of the LSSC approach.

concepts.name: Feature Extraction
concepts.description: The process of identifying relevant patterns in raw sleep signals. Performed by deep learning models to inform sleep stage decisions.

concepts.name: Temporal Dynamics Modeling
concepts.description: The ability of a model to capture transitions and persistence in sleep stages over time. Critical for generating physiologically plausible density maps.

concepts.name: Model Interpretability
concepts.description: The clarity with which model decisions can be understood. Improved by using consensus distributions that reflect real expert reasoning.

concepts.name: Scoring Consistency
concepts.description: The degree to which a model’s output aligns with the expected pattern of expert consensus. Measured via cosine similarity and density map analysis.

concepts.name: Cross-Validation
concepts.description: A technique used to assess model performance on unseen data. Implied in the evaluation across multiple datasets, though not explicitly detailed.

concepts.name: Data Augmentation
concepts.description: Techniques to increase dataset size and diversity. Not explicitly mentioned, but implied in the use of multiple databases for generalization.

concepts.name: Sleep Staging
concepts.description: The process of dividing sleep into stages based on physiological signals. The primary task addressed by the automated system.

concepts.name: Neural Network Training
concepts.description: The process of optimizing model parameters using labeled data. In this study, training is guided by soft consensus distributions.

concepts.name: Performance Benchmarking
concepts.description: The comparison of model results against established standards. Used here to evaluate improvement over single-consensus training.

concepts.name: Clinical Validation
concepts.description: The assessment of model outputs against clinical gold standards. The study uses expert consensus as a proxy for clinical truth.

concepts.name: Personalized Sleep Monitoring
concepts.description: The use of automated systems to track individual sleep patterns over time. The improved reliability of the model supports this emerging application.

concepts.name: Temporal Signal Processing
concepts.description: The analysis of time-series physiological data to extract sleep-relevant features. Fundamental to the input representation in sleep scoring models.

concepts.name: Uncertainty Quantification
concepts.description: The estimation of confidence in model predictions. Achieved indirectly through probability distributions in LSSC.

concepts.name: Model Transferability
concepts.description: The ability of a model trained on one dataset to perform well on another. Supported by the use of diverse databases and lightweight architecture.

concepts.name: Sleep Stage Transitions
concepts.description: The changes between sleep stages over time, such as N1 to N2 or REM onset. Accurate modeling is essential for realistic sleep architecture.

methods.name: Soft Consensus Label Smoothing
methods.description: A training technique that replaces single consensus labels with a smoothed probability distribution derived from multiple expert annotations. The method models inter-rater variability as a continuous distribution, allowing the model to learn from both agreement and disagreement patterns.

methods.name: Averaged Cosine Similarity
methods.description: A novel evaluation metric that computes the mean cosine similarity between the model’s predicted sleep density map and the expert consensus across all time points. It quantifies how well the model captures the temporal structure and pattern of sleep stages.

methods.name: Multi-Expert Annotation Integration
methods.description: A method for aggregating labels from multiple sleep experts into a single probabilistic input for model training. Instead of averaging or voting, it preserves the full distribution of annotations as a soft label.

methods.name: Lightweight Model Training
methods.description: The use of computationally efficient deep learning architectures to train models on multi-scored sleep data. This enables faster inference and deployment, demonstrating scalability of the LSSC approach.

methods.name: Experimental Validation
methods.description: A controlled study design using three publicly available multi-scored sleep databases to train and evaluate models under consistent conditions. Ensures reproducibility and generalizability of results.

methods.name: Label Distribution Modeling
methods.description: A technique to represent expert annotations as empirical probability distributions over sleep stages. This distribution is used as the target during training to guide model learning.

methods.name: Density Map Generation
methods.description: A post-processing step where model outputs are transformed into continuous sleep stage density functions over time. These maps are used for comparison with expert consensus.

methods.name: Cross-Dataset Evaluation
methods.description: The assessment of model performance across multiple independent sleep databases to test generalization. Used to validate robustness and applicability beyond a single dataset.

methods.name: Performance Comparison
methods.description: A method to benchmark the proposed LSSC approach against traditional single-consensus training. Metrics include cosine similarity and model accuracy across datasets.

methods.name: Probability-Based Training
methods.description: A training paradigm where the model is optimized using soft labels (probability distributions) instead of hard one-hot labels. This improves robustness and captures uncertainty.

methods.name: Consensus Distribution Estimation
methods.description: A statistical method to compute the empirical distribution of expert annotations for each time segment. This forms the basis of the soft consensus label.

methods.name: Temporal Smoothing
methods.description: A technique applied to model outputs to ensure smooth transitions between sleep stages, improving physiological plausibility of the generated density maps.

methods.name: Model Output Calibration
methods.description: A post-hoc adjustment to ensure that model confidence scores align with actual prediction accuracy. Supported by the use of soft labels during training.

methods.name: Data Preprocessing
methods.description: Standardization and normalization of polysomnographic signals (e.g., EEG, EOG, EMG) to ensure consistent input to the deep learning models.

methods.name: Epoch-Level Labeling
methods.description: The assignment of sleep stage labels to fixed time windows (typically 30 seconds) based on expert annotations. Forms the basis of the input data structure.

methods.name: Model Architecture Design
methods.description: The selection and configuration of lightweight deep learning models optimized for sleep scoring tasks, emphasizing efficiency and scalability.

methods.name: Training Loss Optimization
methods.description: The use of a loss function (e.g., cross-entropy) adapted to handle soft labels, enabling the model to learn from probabilistic targets derived from expert distributions.

methods.name: Performance Metrics Reporting
methods.description: The systematic documentation of evaluation results using both standard and novel metrics, including average cosine similarity and accuracy across datasets.

methods.name: Robustness Testing
methods.description: An implicit method to assess model behavior under varying levels of expert disagreement, though not explicitly detailed in the paper.

methods.name: Cross-Validation
methods.description: A standard technique used to evaluate model performance on unseen data by partitioning the dataset into training and testing sets. Implied in the evaluation design.
